text.p: Consider the vectors [mathjaxinline]v_1, v_2, v_3 \in \mathbb R^2[/mathjaxinline] as given in this picture:
Which of the following lists are linearly independent? Click all that apply.

font.p:
The zero vector is not linearly independent as a set because [mathjaxinline]a_1 \cdot \mathbf{0}= \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline] for any scalar [mathjaxinline]a_1[/mathjaxinline].
[mathjaxinline]v_1[/mathjaxinline] is linearly independent as a set because [mathjaxinline]v_1[/mathjaxinline] is not the zero vector, and therefore [mathjaxinline]a_1 \cdot v_1 = \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline] implies [mathjaxinline]a_1 = 0[/mathjaxinline].
It can be seen on the diagram that [mathjaxinline]v_1[/mathjaxinline] is not collinear with [mathjaxinline]v_2[/mathjaxinline], and likewise not with [mathjaxinline]v_3[/mathjaxinline], and so [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1;v_2\}[/mathjaxinline] is linearly independent and [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1;v_3\}[/mathjaxinline] is linearly independent.
[mathjaxinline]v_2[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]v_3[/mathjaxinline] appear to be collinear, so [mathjaxinline]\{ v_2;v_3\}[/mathjaxinline] is not linearly independent(i.e. suppose [mathjaxinline]v_3 = 2\cdot v_2[/mathjaxinline]; then 2·v_2 + -1 ·v_3 = 0).
[mathjaxinline]v_3[/mathjaxinline] is of course collinear with itself, so [mathjaxinline]\{ v_3;v_3\}[/mathjaxinline] is not linearly independent.
Finally, since [mathjaxinline]\{ v_2;v_3\}[/mathjaxinline] is not linearly independent and is a subset of [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1;v_2;v_3\}[/mathjaxinline], this last set cannot be linearly independent.
